data.text: @tomgrundy @ssurayaa Nothing to worry, last two weeks 10 of my friends tested positive for Covid19. All of them only had mild symptom such asrunning nose and cough. All of them already got their 2nd vaccine.

@joebeattie @Jason42146758 @tomgrundy For PCR that's the case because they're designed to be very sensitive. Rapid tests are designed to give low false positive rates and to not be very sensitive at a reduced cost.
@winsonliu @MarkCai54389518 @tomgrundy And no mandates anywhere have slowed the omicron curve. No where

@winsonliu @MarkCai54389518 @tomgrundy Explain how if 100,000-150.000 people a day are getting infected how about 1,5m are not actively infected at any one time? It’s take about a week or more to be cured

@BobsYou82437555 @MarkCai54389518 @tomgrundy Your 2nd sentence is inaccurate based on how the virus has played out in all other countries when there are mandates enforced to slow the curve. You need to look at data outside of your region. And talking like a jackass will only make you look like a fool
@winsonliu In hk it’s 100,000 a day. As I said 20% of the population is positive and infectious right now. That’s the point
@winsonliu Who’s disagreeing with that? Not me

@BobsYou82437555 Hence people should quarantine when positive. Just because you have had it doesn’t meant you’ll forever be positive. There’s scientific proof and world data to support that. People should do their part to not incidentally spread.

@BobsYou82437555 My point #2 is offbase, but the other two points are still valid. You can’t extrapolate incident data to the entire population. And no matter what country, vast majority of positive tests are negative within 2-3 months, where average cases will test negative after 2 weeks
